Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hybrid Organic-Inorganic Thermoelectric Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal 1400246
Collaborative Research: Hybrid organic-inorganic thermoelectric materials

Abstract:

Thermoelectric materials are materials which can be used to convert thermal energy directly to electricity. The performance of a thermoelectric material is measured by the "figure of merit", termed ZT. There has been much research into increasing thermoelectric materials, figure of merit, however, progress in this area has been slow and most of the researched thermoelectric materials up to now are suffering from either high fabrication cost, usage of rare earth or toxic elements, or poor mechanical properties. Organic thermoelectric materials (OTEs) have recently attracted attention for low temperature applications (< 300K), especially cooling purposes, as they are flexible, low-cost and abundant, and low-cost fabrication methods for synthesizing them exist. However, the ZT of the state-of-the-art OTEs is significantly lower than the ZT of their inorganic counterparts. In fact, there are only few candidates for low temperature thermoelectric devices even among inorganic materials. In the case of inorganic thermoelectric materials, the limiting factor in improving ZT is the electron mobility. This work will allow for the fabrication of high-ZT thermoelectric materials by addressing the challenges in mobility enhancement. This will be done by combining the two classes of materials (organic and inorganic), using a fabrication scheme in which high-mobility inorganic nanowires are embedded inside organic compounds. The researchers are a multidisciplinary team with complementary expertise and with common interest in the thermoelectric field. Graduate and Undergraduate Students involved in this project therefore will benefit largely from the multidisciplinary nature of the work.

This work is applying new doping schemes (3D modulation-doping and field-effect doping) to hybrid organic-inorganic materials and to simulate, design, fabricate and characterize a new class of low temperature thermoelectric nanocomposites. The two-phase material uses the organic phase (e.g. conjugated-polymer or organic molecules) as a source of electrons and the inorganic semiconducting phase (e.g. Si nanowires) as the electron transport channel with high mobility. The key is to use the modulation-doping scheme to favor carrier transfer from the source of carriers (e.g. conjugated-polymer) to the high mobility inorganic semiconducting phase (inorganic nanowires) and optimize the carrier concentration to design a high Z hybrid thermoelectric material. A large class of semiconducting nanostructures (e.g. Si, CdTe, Bi, and PbTe nanowires and holely structures) combined with conjugated polymers (e.g., chemically-modified PEDOT and low bandgap polymers) and organic molecules (specifically charged chemical species attached to molecules such as CF3- substituted styrene molecules) will be simulated, synthesized and optimized to identify new hybrid materials with a potentially high ZT.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Outcomes Report

Public Release: Not Reviewed by NSF Project Officer

The overall goal of this NSF-funded multi-university initiative was to achieve high thermoelectric energy conversion efficiency using nanoporous silicon/ organic hybrid nanocomposites, with the organic materials serving as modulation dopants. The recipients at UCSB recognized the following sub-goals:

1. To develop experimentally verified, physics-based models of heat transfer in micro- and nano-structured semiconductor crystals.

2. To reduce thermal conductivity of bulk silicon through electron-beam lithographed nanoscale pores. This would minimize the amount of power lost to the thermal-electrical energy conversion process

3. To develop manufacturing processes for aggressively scaling the packing density and diameter of nanometer-scale pores.

The key achievements of the UCSB-based initiative, with achievement indicator defined for purposes of this report as intellectual merit recognized by independent peer-review, or by a physical manufactured product that represents an improvement over the state of the art, were:

1. We constructed models of micro/nano-scale heat transfer for realistic structures (i.e. as opposed to one-dimensional idealizations) that were computationally tractable, mathematically rigorous, physics-based (i.e. non-empirical) and experimentally validated. These models were published in two journal articles (Journal of Applied Physics and Journal of Heat Transfer).

2. We reported on the correct procedure for delineation of the thermal conductivity spectrum from thermo-optic measurements. This work was published in one journal article (Applied Physics Letters).

3. We developed a new electrical probe of the thermal conductivity spectrum that enabled accurate and inexpensive measurement. The experiment and its results were reported in an article in the prestigious journal Nature Scientific Reports.

4. We manufactured nanopatterned silicon films with a scientifically significant and novel feature: a dense array of deep-nanoscale pores (55 nm pores with a 95 nm pitch) etched into the silicon film by electron-beam lithography. We confirmed the pore diameter and density with scanning electron microscope (SEM) imaging. The key challenge faced was that of maintaining the high aspect ratio (1:4) of vertical etch required to prevent the densely packed holes from merging with their neighbors. This challenge was solved by our nanoscale processing team.

We now summarize the impact of the activities at UCSB under the umbrella of this project:

1. On the principal disciplines of the project: Heat transfer and thermoelectrics

1a.) Our heat transfer models have a mathematical structure designed to be similar to the well-known Fourier law, thus enabling nano-scale thermal simulations with minor modifications to existing computational infrastructure.

1b.) Utilizing structures that encourage circulation of the lines of heat-flux, we have outlined a novel strategy for independent control of phonon and electron transport properties, a central concept in high-efficiency thermoelectrics.

1c.) We have introduced a “promising and novel” method for exploring the thermal conductivity spectra of materials, in the words of the peer reviewer for Nature Scientific Reports. This experimental probe has yielded new information that is in conflict with atomistic simulations. This affords an opportunity to improve the accuracy of such “first-principles” attempts at understanding heat transfer.

2. On other scientific disciplines:

2a.) Our solutions of the Boltzmann transport equation (the book-keeping equation of semi-classical transport physics) are likely to enable fast, accurate thermal simulations of semiconductor logic and power devices, which will have a large impact on electronic design automation and gallium nitride power electronics design.
